canonical_explanation.text: Kinematics is the branch of mechanics that describes the motion of objects without considering the forces causing the motion. Motion is described using quantities such as displacement (a vector), velocity (rate of change of displacement) and acceleration (rate of change of velocity). For uniformly accelerated motion in a straight line, the three kinematic equations — v = u + at, s = ut + ½at², and v² = u² + 2as — relate initial velocity u, final velocity v, acceleration a, displacement s and time t. Graphical analysis of displacement-time, velocity-time and acceleration-time graphs provides additional insight: the slope of an s-t graph gives velocity, the slope of a v-t graph gives acceleration, and the area under a v-t graph gives displacement. Motion in two dimensions includes projectile motion (a combination of uniform horizontal motion and uniformly accelerated vertical motion under gravity) and uniform circular motion (constant speed along a circular path with centripetal acceleration v²/r directed towards the centre). Vector algebra — addition, subtraction, resolution into rectangular components and the use of unit vectors — is essential for analysing two-dimensional motion and relative velocity problems.
rules: Displacement is a vector (shortest path from start to end); distance is a scalar (total path length).
The three equations of uniformly accelerated motion are: v = u + at, s = ut + ½at², and v² = u² + 2as, valid only when acceleration is constant.
For projectile motion on level ground: time of flight T = 2u sinθ/g, maximum height H = u² sin²θ/(2g), range R = u² sin 2θ/g.
In uniform circular motion the centripetal acceleration a = v²/r is always directed towards the centre of the circle.
Relative velocity of A with respect to B is v_AB = v_A − v_B (vector subtraction).

questions.question_text: Displacement is a vector quantity because it has:
questions.explanation_correct: Displacement is a vector quantity because it has both magnitude (the numerical value of the distance moved) and direction (the path the object takes). This is in contrast to scalar quantities like distance, which only have magnitude and no direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Displacement is not just a quantity with magnitude (a number) or just a quantity with direction (a direction). Displacement is a vector, which means it has both magnitude and direction. The correct answer is that displacement has both magnitude and direction, not just one or the other.

questions.question_text: The average velocity of an object that travels 100 m east and then 60 m west in a total time of 20 s is:
questions.explanation_correct: The average velocity is the total displacement divided by the total time. The total displacement is the net displacement, which is 100 m east - 60 m west = 40 m east. The total time is 20 s, so the average velocity is 40 m / 20 s = 2 m/s east.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the total displacement is 40 m east, not 100 m east. Option C is incorrect because the average velocity must take into account the direction of motion - just the magnitude of the displacement divided by the time is not enough. Option D is incorrect because the average velocity is not 3 m/s east, it is 2 m/s east.

questions.question_text: An object moves along a circle of radius 10 m and returns to its starting point. Its distance and displacement are:
questions.explanation_correct: The object moves along a circular path of radius 10 m and returns to its starting point. The distance traveled is the circumference of the circle, which is 20π m. However, the displacement, which is the vector distance from the starting point to the ending point, is zero since the object returns to its original position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because the distance traveled by the object is 20π m, which is the circumference of the circular path. The displacement, however, is zero since the object returns to its starting point after moving along the circle. Even though the distance traveled is 20π m, the displacement is zero.

questions.question_text: A car accelerates uniformly from rest to 20 m/s in 5 s. Its acceleration is:
questions.explanation_correct: The acceleration of the car is given by the formula a = (v - u) / t, where a is acceleration, v is final velocity, u is initial velocity, and t is time. Plugging in the given values of v = 20 m/s, u = 0 m/s, and t = 5 s, we get a = (20 - 0) / 5 = 4 m/s², which matches the correct answer B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are based on incorrect calculations. Option A (2 m/s²) is too low, as the car goes from 0 to 20 m/s in 5 seconds. Options C (5 m/s²) and D (10 m/s²) are too high, as they do not match the given information about the car's acceleration from rest to 20 m/s in 5 seconds.

questions.question_text: The area under a velocity-time graph represents:
questions.explanation_correct: The area under a velocity-time graph represents the total displacement or distance traveled. This is because velocity is the rate of change of displacement, and the area under a velocity-time graph is the integral of velocity with respect to time, which gives the change in displacement or distance covered.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The area under a velocity-time graph does not represent acceleration, speed, or force. Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity, and is represented by the slope of the velocity-time graph. Speed is the magnitude of velocity, not the area under the graph. Force is not directly related to the area under a velocity-time graph, as it is a separate kinematic quantity.

questions.question_text: A body starting from rest moves with uniform acceleration of 2 m/s². The distance covered by the body in the 5th second is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 9 m. This is because for a body starting from rest with uniform acceleration, the distance covered in the 5th second is given by the formula s = ut + 1/2 at², where u = 0 (starting from rest), a = 2 m/s², and t = 5 s. Plugging these values, we get s = 1/2 × 2 × 5² = 9 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not follow the formula for distance covered in the 5th second for a body starting from rest with uniform acceleration. Option A) 7 m and Option C) 11 m do not match the correct value of 9 m calculated using the formula. Option D) 25 m is incorrect because it is the total distance covered in 5 seconds, not just the distance in the 5th second.

questions.question_text: A ball is thrown vertically upward with a velocity of 30 m/s. The maximum height reached is (take g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 45 m. When a ball is thrown upward, its velocity decreases due to the constant downward acceleration of gravity (g = 10 m/s²). At the maximum height, the ball's velocity becomes zero before it starts falling down. Using the kinematic equation v² = u² + 2as, where u = 30 m/s, a = -10 m/s², and v = 0 at the maximum height, we can calculate the maximum height s = 45 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are: A) 30 m, C) 60 m, and D) 90 m. Option A is incorrect because the maximum height reached is not equal to the initial upward velocity. Option C is incorrect because the maximum height is not double the initial upward velocity. Option D is incorrect because the maximum height is not three times the initial upward velocity. The correct answer is B) 45 m, which can be calculated using the kinematic equation v² = u² + 2as.

questions.question_text: A car travelling at 72 km/h applies brakes and comes to rest in 5 s. The braking distance is:
questions.explanation_correct: The braking distance can be calculated using the kinematic equation s = ut + 1/2 at^2, where s is the distance, u is the initial velocity, t is the time, and a is the acceleration. Given the initial velocity of 72 km/h (20 m/s) and the time taken to come to rest (5 s), the braking distance can be calculated as 50 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly apply the kinematic equations. Option B (100 m) and Option C (200 m) are too large for the given time and initial velocity, while Option D (25 m) is too small. The correct answer of 50 m is obtained by using the kinematic equation s = ut + 1/2 at^2 with the given information.

questions.question_text: The trajectory of a projectile is a:
questions.explanation_correct: The trajectory of a projectile is a parabola because the motion of a projectile is a combination of uniform horizontal motion and uniformly accelerated vertical motion due to gravity. The vertical motion follows a parabolic path, while the horizontal motion is linear.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The trajectory of a projectile is not a straight line, circle, or hyperbola. This is because a projectile's motion is a combination of horizontal and vertical motion, which results in a parabolic trajectory. The horizontal motion is uniform, while the vertical motion is uniformly accelerated due to the force of gravity. This combination of motions leads to a parabolic path, which is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: A projectile is launched at 30° to the horizontal with a speed of 40 m/s. Its range is (take g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 80√3 m. This can be calculated using the equation for the range of a projectile: R = (v₀² × sin(2θ))/g, where v₀ is the initial speed, θ is the angle of launch, and g is the acceleration due to gravity. Plugging in the given values, we get R = (40² × sin(60°))/10 = 80√3 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not properly account for the launch angle and initial speed of the projectile. Option B) 80 m is incorrect because it assumes the projectile is launched horizontally, which is not the case. Option C) 160 m is incorrect because it doubles the correct range. Option D) 40√3 m is incorrect because it does not consider the launch angle and only uses the horizontal component of the initial velocity.

questions.question_text: For a projectile launched at angle θ from level ground, the maximum height is greatest when θ equals:
questions.explanation_correct: The maximum height of a projectile is greatest when the launch angle is 90°, which corresponds to the projectile being launched vertically upwards. This is because a vertical launch maximizes the time the projectile spends in the air, allowing it to reach the maximum possible height before falling back down.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The maximum height of a projectile is not greatest at 30°, 45°, or 60° launch angles. These angles will produce a maximum height that is less than the maximum height achieved with a 90° launch angle. This is because a vertical launch (90°) maximizes the time the projectile spends in the air, allowing it to reach the greatest possible height before falling back down.

questions.question_text: A projectile is launched at 45° with speed u. The ratio of maximum height to range is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 1:4. For a projectile launched at an angle θ with initial speed u, the maximum height is given by h_max = u²sin²θ/2g, and the range is given by R = u²sin2θ/g. The ratio of h_max to R is (u²sin²θ/2g) / (u²sin2θ/g) = 1/4, which is 1:4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options B) 1:2, C) 1:1, and D) 2:1 are not correct because they do not match the actual ratio of maximum height to range for a projectile launched at an angle. The correct ratio is 1:4, as derived from the kinematic equations for projectile motion.

questions.question_text: A body moves in a circle of radius 2 m with a constant speed of 4 m/s. The magnitude of centripetal acceleration is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 8 m/s². In uniform circular motion, the centripetal acceleration is given by the formula a = v²/r, where v is the constant speed and r is the radius of the circle. Plugging in the given values of v = 4 m/s and r = 2 m, we get a = (4 m/s)²/(2 m) = 8 m/s².
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are: A) 2 m/s² - this is too low, as the formula shows the acceleration is inversely proportional to the radius; B) 4 m/s² - this is also too low, as the acceleration depends on the square of the speed; D) 16 m/s² - this is too high, as the acceleration is proportional to the square of the speed, not its fourth power.

questions.question_text: Two cars A and B move in the same direction with speeds 60 km/h and 40 km/h respectively. The velocity of A relative to B is:

options.text: 20 km/h in the direction of motion
100 km/h in the direction of motion
20 km/h opposite to the direction of motion

questions.explanation_correct: The velocity of car A relative to car B is the difference between their individual velocities. Since car A is moving at 60 km/h and car B is moving at 40 km/h in the same direction, the relative velocity of A with respect to B is 60 km/h - 40 km/h = 20 km/h in the direction of motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is incorrect because the relative velocity of A with respect to B is not the sum of their individual velocities, which would be 100 km/h. Option C is incorrect because the relative velocity is in the same direction as the motion, not opposite to it. Option D is incorrect because the relative velocity is not simply the speed of car B, but the difference between the speeds of the two cars.

questions.question_text: A man can swim at 3 m/s in still water. A river flows at 4 m/s. To cross the river perpendicularly, he should swim at an angle to the upstream direction. The resultant speed of the man across the river is not possible if the river speed exceeds his swimming speed. In this case, the minimum drift speed downstream is:

options.text: He cannot cross without drifting; minimum downstream component using best angle gives √7 m/s ≈ 2.65 m/s

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is D because if the river speed (4 m/s) exceeds the swimmer's speed (3 m/s), the swimmer will not be able to cross the river perpendicularly. The minimum downstream drift speed would be the resultant of the river speed and the swimmer's speed at the best angle, which is √(3^2 + 4^2) ≈ 2.65 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not represent the minimum downstream drift speed when the swimmer cannot cross the river perpendicularly. Option A (1 m/s) is too low, Option B (4 m/s) is equal to the river speed, and Option C (5 m/s) is too high. The correct answer is D, which represents the minimum downstream drift speed using the best angle when the swimmer cannot cross the river perpendicularly.

questions.question_text: Rain falls vertically at 10 m/s. A man walks at 10 m/s. The angle at which he should hold his umbrella with the vertical is:
questions.explanation_correct: The angle at which the man should hold his umbrella with the vertical is 45° because the rain falls vertically at 10 m/s and the man walks at 10 m/s, which creates a resultant motion at 45° to the vertical.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 45°, not 30°, 60°, or 90°. At 45°, the umbrella is held at the angle where the vertical motion of the rain and the horizontal motion of the man's walking combine to create a resultant motion. 30° and 60° are incorrect as they do not represent the correct angle where the vertical and horizontal motions combine. 90° is also incorrect as it would mean the umbrella is held parallel to the ground, which does not account for the man's horizontal motion.

questions.question_text: The resultant of two vectors of magnitudes 3 N and 4 N acting at right angles to each other is:
questions.explanation_correct: The resultant of two vectors acting at right angles is given by the Pythagorean theorem, which states that the magnitude of the resultant is the square root of the sum of the squares of the magnitudes of the two vectors. In this case, the magnitudes are 3 N and 4 N, so the resultant is √(3²+4²) = √(9+16) = √25 = 5 N.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is the correct answer. The two vectors of magnitudes 3 N and 4 N are acting at right angles, so the resultant can be calculated using the Pythagorean theorem. The incorrect options do not correctly apply this theorem to find the resultant magnitude.

questions.question_text: The unit vector along the x-axis is denoted by:
questions.explanation_correct: The unit vector along the x-axis is denoted by the symbol 'î'. This is because 'î' represents the unit vector in the positive x-direction, which is a fundamental vector in the Cartesian coordinate system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options, ĵ, k̂, and r̂, represent the unit vectors in the y-direction, z-direction, and radial direction, respectively. These are not the unit vector in the x-direction, which is the answer to this question.

questions.question_text: A vector of magnitude 10 makes an angle of 60° with the x-axis. Its x-component is:
questions.explanation_correct: The x-component of a vector is given by the product of the vector's magnitude and the cosine of the angle it makes with the x-axis. Since the vector has a magnitude of 10 and makes an angle of 60° with the x-axis, the x-component is 10 × cos(60°) = 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly calculate the x-component. Option A of 10 is incorrect because the x-component is less than the total magnitude. Option C of 5√3 is incorrect because it does not take the cosine of the 60° angle. Option D of 10√3 is incorrect because it does not divide the magnitude by 2 to get the x-component.

questions.question_text: Two vectors A = 3î + 4ĵ and B = 4î − 3ĵ. The magnitude of A + B is:
questions.explanation_correct: The magnitude of the vector A + B is the square root of the sum of the squares of the components, which is √(3^2 + 4^2 + 4^2 - 3^2) = √50.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C) √50. To find the magnitude of the vector A + B, we add the components of the two vectors: A = 3i + 4j and B = 4i - 3j. The resulting vector has components (3 + 4) i + (4 - 3) j = 7i + j. The magnitude of this vector is the square root of the sum of the squares of the components, which is √(7^2 + 1^2) = √50.

questions.question_text: A stone is dropped from a height of 80 m. The time taken to fall the last 20 m is (take g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C, 4 - √12 s ≈ 0.54 s. This can be calculated using the kinematic equation s = 1/2 at^2, where s is the displacement (20 m), a is the acceleration due to gravity (10 m/s^2), and t is the time taken to fall the last 20 m. Solving this equation gives the correct time of 4 - √12 s ≈ 0.54 s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not properly apply the kinematic equations to solve for the time taken to fall the last 20 m. Option A (0.5 s) is too fast, Option B (1.0 s) is too slow, and Option D (2.0 s) is also too slow. The correct option C uses the kinematic equation s = 1/2 at^2 to calculate the time taken for the stone to fall the last 20 m.

questions.question_text: Two bodies are dropped from heights h and 2h simultaneously. The ratio of times taken by them to reach the ground is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 1 : √2. This is because the time taken by an object to fall from a height is proportional to the square root of the height. Since the heights are in the ratio 1 : 2, the time taken to reach the ground will be in the ratio √1 : √2, which is 1 : √2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not accurately represent the relationship between the time taken by the two bodies to reach the ground. Option A) 1 : 2 is incorrect because the time taken is proportional to the square root of the height, not the height itself. Option C) √2 : 1 is incorrect because it is the reciprocal of the correct ratio. Option D) 1 : 4 is incorrect because it does not account for the square root relationship between time and height.

questions.question_text: A ball is thrown horizontally from a cliff 80 m high with a speed of 20 m/s. The horizontal distance from the base of the cliff where the ball hits the ground is (g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 80 m. Since the ball is thrown horizontally, its horizontal motion is uniform (constant velocity) while its vertical motion is uniformly accelerated (due to gravity). Using the kinematic equations for horizontal and vertical motion, we can calculate the horizontal distance travelled by the ball as it falls to the ground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not properly account for the combination of horizontal and vertical motion. The ball's horizontal velocity remains constant at 20 m/s, but its vertical velocity changes due to gravity. By applying the kinematic equations for both horizontal and vertical motion, we can determine that the ball hits the ground 80 m horizontally from the base of the cliff.

questions.question_text: The velocity-time graph of an object is a straight line with a negative slope. This means the object is:
questions.explanation_correct: A straight line with a negative slope in a velocity-time graph indicates that the object is decelerating uniformly, meaning its velocity is decreasing at a constant rate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object is not at rest (option A) because the graph shows its velocity is changing over time. It is also not moving with uniform velocity (option B) since the slope of the graph is non-zero. The object is not accelerating uniformly (option D) as the graph has a negative slope, indicating deceleration rather than acceleration.

questions.question_text: The time of flight of a projectile launched at 60° with speed 20 m/s is (g = 10 m/s²):
questions.explanation_correct: The time of flight of a projectile launched at an angle of 60° with an initial speed of 20 m/s is 2√3 seconds. This is because the vertical component of the initial velocity is 20sin(60°) = 10√3 m/s, and the acceleration due to gravity is 10 m/s². Using the kinematic equation v = u + at, we can calculate the time of flight as 2√3 seconds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (2 seconds) is incorrect because the time of flight for a projectile launched at 60° with an initial speed of 20 m/s is not 2 seconds. Option C (4 seconds) is incorrect because the time of flight is not 4 seconds. Option D (3 seconds) is incorrect because the time of flight is not 3 seconds. The correct answer is 2√3 seconds, as calculated using the kinematic equations for projectile motion.

questions.question_text: If |A + B| = |A − B|, then the angle between vectors A and B is:
questions.explanation_correct: If the magnitude of the vector sum |A + B| is equal to the magnitude of the vector difference |A - B|, then the angle between the vectors A and B is 90 degrees, or perpendicular to each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The angle between vectors A and B cannot be 0 degrees (option A) because that would imply the vectors are parallel and pointing in the same direction. Similarly, the angle cannot be 60 degrees (option B) or 180 degrees (option D) because those do not satisfy the given condition of |A + B| = |A - B|. The correct answer is 90 degrees (option C) because this ensures the vectors are perpendicular to each other, which is the only way for the magnitudes of the vector sum and vector difference to be equal.

questions.question_text: A body with initial velocity 10 m/s decelerates at 2 m/s². The distance it travels before coming to rest is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 25 m. Using the kinematic equation v^2 = u^2 + 2as, where v = 0 (final velocity), u = 10 m/s (initial velocity), and a = -2 m/s^2 (deceleration), we can calculate the distance s = 25 m before the body comes to rest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are A) 10 m, C) 50 m, and D) 100 m. Option A is too short because the body has an initial velocity of 10 m/s and decelerates at 2 m/s^2, so it would travel more than 10 m before coming to rest. Options C and D are too long because they do not correctly apply the kinematic equation v^2 = u^2 + 2as to find the distance travelled.

questions.question_text: The instantaneous velocity of a particle is defined as the:

options.text: Total displacement divided by total time
Limit of average velocity as time interval approaches zero
Total distance divided by total time

questions.explanation_correct: The instantaneous velocity of a particle is the limit of the average velocity as the time interval approaches zero. This is because average velocity is calculated as the total displacement divided by the total time, but as the time interval gets smaller, the average velocity approaches the instantaneous velocity at that point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A and C are incorrect because they represent the average velocity, not the instantaneous velocity. Option D is also incorrect because the instantaneous velocity is the rate of change of displacement, not acceleration.

questions.question_text: A boat can travel at 5 m/s in still water. It crosses a river flowing at 3 m/s by heading perpendicular to the current. The resultant speed of the boat is:
questions.explanation_correct: The resultant speed of the boat is the vector addition of its speed in still water (5 m/s) and the speed of the river current (3 m/s). Using Pythagoras theorem, the resultant speed is √(5^2 + 3^2) = √34 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not account for the vector nature of the boat's motion. Option A (2 m/s) is the difference between the boat's speed and the river current, which is not the resultant speed. Option B (4 m/s) is the sum of the boat's speed and the river current, which is also not the resultant speed. Option D (8 m/s) is the vector addition of the boat's speed and twice the river current, which is incorrect.

questions.question_text: A particle moves in a circle of radius 0.5 m with angular velocity 4π rad/s. Its centripetal acceleration is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 8π² m/s². This is because the centripetal acceleration of a particle moving in a circle is given by the formula a = v²/r, where v is the speed and r is the radius of the circle. In this case, the angular velocity is 4π rad/s, and the radius is 0.5 m, so the speed is v = 2πr × ω = 4π × 0.5 = 2π m/s. Plugging this into the formula, we get a = (2π)²/0.5 = 8π² m/s².
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly apply the formula for centripetal acceleration. Option A) 2π² m/s² is incorrect because it uses the angular velocity instead of the speed. Option C) 4π² m/s² is incorrect because it uses the radius instead of the speed. Option D) 16π² m/s² is incorrect because it uses both the angular velocity and the radius incorrectly.

questions.question_text: A ball is thrown vertically upward with velocity u. Another ball is thrown after a time t with the same velocity. They meet at a height:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C, (4u² - g²t²)/(8g). This is because when the two balls meet at a height, the time elapsed for the first ball to reach that height is t/2, and the distance traveled is (u*t/2) - (g*t²/8). Equating the heights of the two balls gives the expression (4u² - g²t²)/(8g).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not accurately represent the height at which the two balls meet. Option A, ut/2 - gt²/8, does not account for the fact that the second ball is launched after a time t. Option B, u²/(2g), gives the maximum height reached by the first ball, but not the height at which the two balls meet. Option D, ut - gt²/2, gives the total distance traveled by the first ball, not the height at which the two balls meet.

questions.question_text: A boat crosses a 200 m wide river in minimum time. The boat speed in still water is 5 m/s and river speed is 3 m/s. The minimum crossing time is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 40 s. To find the minimum time for the boat to cross the 200 m wide river, we need to consider the boat's speed in still water (5 m/s) and the river's speed (3 m/s). The boat will have to move diagonally across the river, and the minimum time corresponds to the shortest path, which is the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle with sides of 200 m and 3 m/s. Using the Pythagorean theorem, the minimum time is calculated as 200 / sqrt(5^2 - 3^2) = 40 s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because they do not consider the boat's speed in still water and the river's speed. B) 50 s is too long, C) 25 s is too short, and D) 33.3 s is also incorrect as it does not represent the minimum time for the boat to cross the river.

questions.question_text: The magnitude of the resultant of two equal vectors of magnitude F acting at an angle of 120° to each other is:
questions.explanation_correct: The magnitude of the resultant of two equal vectors of magnitude F acting at an angle of 120° to each other is F. This is because the parallelogram formed by the two vectors has one diagonal of length 2F, so the magnitude of the resultant is F.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly calculate the resultant of two equal vectors acting at 120° to each other. Option A (F/2) is incorrect because the resultant of two equal vectors cannot be half the magnitude of the individual vectors. Option C (F√2) is incorrect because the resultant is not the diagonal of the parallelogram formed by the two vectors. Option D (2F) is incorrect because the resultant is not twice the magnitude of the individual vectors.

questions.question_text: A body starts from rest and travels distances s₁ and s₂ in the first and second seconds respectively. The ratio s₁ : s₂ is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 1 : 3. This is because for a body starting from rest and undergoing constant acceleration, the distance travelled in the first and second seconds is proportional to the square of the time. Since the distance in the first second is s₁, and in the second second is s₂, the ratio s₁ : s₂ is 1 : 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not follow the relationship between the distances travelled in the first and second seconds for a body starting from rest and undergoing constant acceleration. The correct ratio is 1 : 3, as the distance travelled is proportional to the square of the time, and the time difference between the first and second seconds is 1 second.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a scalar quantity?
questions.explanation_correct: Speed is a scalar quantity, as it only has a magnitude (numerical value) and no direction. Velocity, on the other hand, is a vector quantity as it has both magnitude and direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Velocity and acceleration are both vector quantities, as they have both magnitude and direction. Displacement is also a vector quantity. Only speed, which is the magnitude of velocity, is a scalar quantity.

questions.question_text: Average speed can be zero if the object returns to its starting point.
questions.explanation_correct: Average speed is calculated as the total distance travelled divided by the total time taken. If an object returns to its starting point, the total distance travelled is zero, so the average speed would be zero as well.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The average speed of an object cannot be zero if it returns to its starting point. This is because the object has travelled some distance, even if it ends up back where it started. The total distance travelled would be non-zero, so the average speed cannot be zero.

questions.question_text: The equations of motion v = u + at and s = ut + ½at² are valid only when acceleration is constant.
questions.explanation_correct: The equations of motion v = u + at and s = ut + ½at² are valid only when acceleration is constant, meaning it does not change over time. This is because these equations are derived under the assumption of constant acceleration, which allows us to relate the initial velocity, final velocity, acceleration, displacement, and time in a simple way.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The equations of motion v = u + at and s = ut + ½at² are not valid when acceleration is not constant. This is because these equations are derived under the specific assumption that acceleration is constant over time. If acceleration is changing, then these equations do not accurately describe the motion, and more complex equations would be needed.

questions.question_text: The horizontal component of velocity remains constant throughout projectile motion (neglecting air resistance).
questions.explanation_correct: In projectile motion, the horizontal component of velocity remains constant throughout the motion, as there is no horizontal force acting on the projectile. This is because the only force acting on the projectile is the downward force of gravity, which does not affect the horizontal motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be that the horizontal component of velocity does not remain constant throughout projectile motion. This is a common misconception, as some students may think that the horizontal velocity changes due to the influence of gravity. However, the key principle to understand is that the horizontal and vertical components of motion in projectile motion are independent, and the horizontal component remains constant as long as air resistance is neglected.

questions.question_text: In uniform circular motion, the speed changes continuously.
questions.explanation_correct: In uniform circular motion, the speed (or magnitude of velocity) remains constant. The velocity vector is constantly changing direction, causing centripetal acceleration, but the speed does not change.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement that 'in uniform circular motion, the speed changes continuously' is incorrect. In uniform circular motion, the object moves at a constant speed along a circular path. The direction of the velocity vector changes continuously, causing centripetal acceleration, but the magnitude of the velocity (the speed) does not change.

questions.question_text: The resultant of two vectors of unequal magnitudes can never be zero.
questions.explanation_correct: The resultant of two vectors can be zero if the two vectors have the same magnitude but are in opposite directions. In this case, the two vectors will cancel each other out, resulting in a resultant of zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The common misconception is that the resultant of two vectors of unequal magnitudes can never be zero. However, this is not true. If the two vectors have the same magnitude but are in opposite directions, their resultant will be zero, regardless of their magnitudes being unequal. The key is the direction of the vectors, not just their magnitudes.

questions.question_text: A body dropped from rest falls a distance of ___ m in 3 seconds (take g = 10 m/s²).
questions.explanation_correct: The body falls with a constant acceleration due to gravity (g = 10 m/s²) from rest. Using the kinematic equation s = 1/2 * a * t², we can calculate the distance fallen in 3 seconds as 1/2 * 10 * 3² = 45 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single number, 45. The incorrect answer might be obtained by using the wrong kinematic equation or missing a step in the calculation. For example, one might try to use the equation v = u + at directly, forgetting that the initial velocity u is 0 m/s. The correct working is to use the equation s = 1/2 * a * t² to find the distance fallen in 3 seconds.

questions.question_text: The range of a projectile is maximum when the angle of projection is ___ degrees.
questions.explanation_correct: The range of a projectile is maximum when the angle of projection is 45 degrees. This is because the vertical and horizontal components of the velocity are equal at this angle, resulting in the projectile reaching the maximum horizontal distance or range.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The range of a projectile is not maximum at 60 degrees. The range is actually maximum when the angle of projection is 45 degrees. At 45 degrees, the vertical and horizontal components of the velocity are equal, which results in the projectile reaching the maximum horizontal distance or range.

questions.question_text: In uniform circular motion, the acceleration is directed towards the ___ of the circle.
questions.explanation_correct: In uniform circular motion, the object moves at a constant speed along a circular path. However, its direction of motion is constantly changing, causing it to experience an acceleration directed towards the center of the circle. This acceleration is called the centripetal acceleration, and it is what keeps the object moving in a circular path.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The acceleration in uniform circular motion is directed towards the centre of the circle, not away from it. This is because the object is constantly changing direction, which requires a force (and thus an acceleration) directed towards the centre to keep it moving in a circular path. The correct answer is 'centre', as the acceleration in uniform circular motion is centripetal, meaning it points towards the center of the circle.

questions.question_text: A car moving at 20 m/s decelerates uniformly at 4 m/s². It stops after ___ seconds.
questions.explanation_correct: The car initially moving at 20 m/s decelerates at 4 m/s². Using the kinematic equation v = u + at, where u = 20 m/s, a = -4 m/s² and v = 0 m/s (since the car stops), we can calculate the time t = 5 seconds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to assume that the car takes a different time to stop, such as 10 seconds. However, this is not correct because the given information, including the initial velocity of 20 m/s and the deceleration of 4 m/s², can be used to calculate the exact time it takes for the car to stop, which is 5 seconds.

questions.question_text: Two vectors of magnitudes 6 and 8 act at right angles. The magnitude of their resultant is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The magnitude of the resultant of two vectors at right angles is given by the Pythagorean Theorem. Since the two vectors have magnitudes of 6 and 8, the magnitude of their resultant is sqrt(6^2 + 8^2) = 10.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to simply add the magnitudes of the two vectors, which is 6 + 8 = 14. However, this is not the correct way to find the magnitude of the resultant of two vectors at right angles. The correct approach is to use the Pythagorean Theorem, which gives the magnitude of the resultant as 10.

questions.question_text: If a train moves east at 60 km/h and another train moves west at 40 km/h, the relative velocity of the first train with respect to the second is ___ km/h eastward.
questions.explanation_correct: The relative velocity between the two trains is calculated by adding their individual velocities in the opposite direction. Since the first train is moving east at 60 km/h and the second train is moving west at 40 km/h, the relative velocity of the first train with respect to the second is 60 km/h + 40 km/h = 100 km/h eastward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 20 km/h eastward. This is because the student may have subtracted the individual velocities instead of adding them, thinking that the relative velocity is the difference between the two train velocities. However, the correct answer is 100 km/h eastward, as the relative velocity is calculated by adding the individual velocities in the opposite direction.

questions.question_text: The slope of a displacement-time graph gives the ___ of the object.
questions.explanation_correct: The slope of the displacement-time graph gives the velocity of the object because velocity is defined as the rate of change of displacement with time. The slope of the graph represents this rate of change, so it directly gives the velocity of the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be something like 'acceleration'. While acceleration is also an important quantity in kinematics, the slope of the displacement-time graph gives the velocity, not the acceleration. Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity, so it would be represented by the slope of the velocity-time graph, not the displacement-time graph.

questions.question_text: A ball is thrown vertically upward. Arrange the following events in chronological order: (A) Ball reaches maximum height, (B) Ball is at half the maximum height going up, (C) Ball returns to the thrower, (D) Ball is at half the maximum height coming down
ordering_items: Ball is at half the maximum height going up
Ball is at half the maximum height coming down
correct_answer: Ball is at half the maximum height going up
Ball is at half the maximum height coming down
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: (B) Ball is at half the maximum height going up, (A) Ball reaches maximum height, (D) Ball is at half the maximum height coming down, (C) Ball returns to the thrower. This is because as the ball is thrown upward, it first reaches half the maximum height, then the maximum height, then it starts coming back down and reaches half the maximum height again before finally returning to the thrower.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: (A) Ball reaches maximum height, (B) Ball is at half the maximum height going up, (C) Ball returns to the thrower, (D) Ball is at half the maximum height coming down. This is incorrect because the ball first reaches half the maximum height going up, then the maximum height, then it starts coming back down and reaches half the maximum height again before finally returning to the thrower. The order of the events is important to understand the complete motion of the ball.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following projectile angles in order of increasing range on level ground (same initial speed): (A) 15°, (B) 30°, (C) 45°, (D) 75°
questions.explanation_correct: The range of a projectile launched at an angle θ on level ground is maximized at an angle of 45°. Therefore, the order of increasing range is 15°, 30°, 45°, 75°, as a larger angle leads to a greater range up to 45°, after which the range decreases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be 15°, 45°, 30°, 75°. This is because the range of a projectile is determined by the launch angle, and it increases as the angle increases up to 45°, after which it decreases. The correct order is 15°, 30°, 45°, 75°, with 45° giving the maximum range.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following speeds in increasing order: (A) 36 km/h, (B) 15 m/s, (C) 1 km/min, (D) 20 m/s
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from lowest to highest speed is: 15 m/s, 36 km/h, 1 km/min, 20 m/s. This is because 15 m/s is lower than 36 km/h (which is approximately 10 m/s), and 1 km/min is equivalent to 16.67 m/s, which is lower than 20 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to place 1 km/min before 15 m/s and 36 km/h. This is because 1 km/min is equivalent to 16.67 m/s, which is higher than both 15 m/s and 36 km/h (approximately 10 m/s). The correct order from lowest to highest speed is 15 m/s, 36 km/h, 1 km/min, 20 m/s.
